name: Hakata Gion Yamakasa
short_description: A high-energy race of massive wooden floats through the streets of Hakata.
description:
Hakata Gion Yamakasa is a 700-year-old festival held at Kushida Shrine in Fukuoka. The highlight is the 'Oiyama' race held at 4:59 AM on July 15th, where seven neighborhoods race 1-ton floats through the city. The festival is a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage and draws millions of spectators.

Throughout early July, massive stationary floats called 'Kazari-yamakasa'—decorated with scenes from folklore or anime—are displayed around the city. The participants wear traditional 'shimekomi' (loincloths) and 'happi' coats. It is a powerful display of community spirit and historical preservation that defines the summer in Fukuoka.

name: Nagasaki Kunchi
short_description: A unique festival blending Japanese, Chinese, and Dutch influences.
description:
Nagasaki Kunchi is the festival of Suwa Shrine, held annually from October 7th to 9th. It is famous for its 'Ja-odori' (Dragon Dance) and floats modeled after Chinese and Dutch ships, reflecting Nagasaki's history as Japan's only open port during the Edo period.

Each year, different neighborhoods (dancing towns) take turns performing over a 7-year cycle. The energy is intense, with performers shouting 'motte koi!' (bring it back!) to request encores. It is widely considered one of Japan's most unique and diverse festivals due to its cosmopolitan roots.

name: Saga International Balloon Fiesta
short_description: Asia's largest hot air balloon competition held on the Kase River.
description:
Held in late October or early November, this international event features over 100 hot air balloons from around the world. The colorful balloons taking off simultaneously against the vast Saga plains is a spectacular sight. The event includes competitive tasks as well as 'Balloon Fantasia,' featuring balloons shaped like animals and characters.

The 'La Montgolfier Nocturne' is a highlight, where balloons are tethered to the ground at night and lit up by their burners in time to music, reflecting in the Kase River. It is one of Kyushu's most popular autumn events, attracting families and photographers from across Japan.

name: Kumamoto Castle Sakura
short_description: Cherry blossoms surrounding one of Japan's most impressive and resilient fortresses.
description:
Kumamoto Castle is one of the 'Three Famous Castles' of Japan. In spring, approximately 800 cherry trees bloom within the castle grounds and along the surrounding moats. The contrast between the black 'kuronurishi' castle walls and the light pink petals is iconic.

Following the 2016 earthquake, the castle has undergone extensive restoration, and the cherry blossom season serves as a symbol of the city's recovery. The castle is illuminated at night, creating a magical atmosphere. The 'Hoate-gomon' gate area is a particularly popular spot for photographs.

name: Takachiho Gorge Koyo
short_description: Fiery autumn leaves framing the volcanic basalt columns and Manai Falls.
description:
Takachiho Gorge is a National Scenic Spot formed by ancient lava flows from Mt. Aso. In November, the trees lining the 100-meter high volcanic cliffs turn brilliant shades of red and gold. The Manai Falls, which drops into the emerald green Gokase River, is the centerpiece of this natural wonder.

Visitors can rent rowboats to experience the autumn colors from the water level, looking up at the towering columns and the canopy above. The area is also deeply connected to Japanese mythology, being the site where the sun goddess Amaterasu is said to have hidden in a cave. The mix of spiritual history and natural beauty is peak during the autumn season.

name: Huis Ten Bosch Kingdom of Lights
short_description: The world's largest illumination event in a Dutch-themed park.
description:
Huis Ten Bosch, a theme park that recreates a Dutch town, hosts the 'Kingdom of Lights' from late autumn through winter. It features over 13 million LED lights, making it one of the largest light displays on earth. Highlights include a canal of light, a 66-meter light waterfall, and projection mapping on the park's European buildings.

The event includes a winter garden with 'Silver World' displays and a massive light organ. Because the park is so large, the illuminations feel like an entire luminous city. It has consistently won awards as the top illumination in Japan for its scale and artistic quality.

name: Kawachi Wisteria Garden
short_description: Spectacular tunnels of purple and white wisteria flowers.
description:
This private garden gained global fame after being listed by CNN as one of 'Japan's 31 most beautiful places.' It is famous for its two 100-meter long wisteria tunnels where various types of wisteria create a gradient of purple, pink, and white. The flowers bloom from late April to early May.

In addition to the tunnels, there is a large dome of wisteria and a hillside offering views of the blooming flowers from above. The garden is also popular in autumn for its maple trees, but the spring wisteria peak is its signature attraction. Due to its popularity, tickets must often be reserved in advance through convenience stores.

name: Nagasaki Lantern Festival
short_description: Over 15,000 Chinese lanterns celebrating the Lunar New Year.
description:
Originally a celebration of the Chinese New Year by Nagasaki's Chinese community, this festival has grown into a major city-wide event held for 15 days in late January or February. The city is decorated with 15,000 colorful lanterns and large-scale light sculptures representing zodiac animals and historical figures.

The festival includes Chinese circus performances, dragon dances, and lion dances. The Minato Park and Chinatown areas are the center of the festivities. The warm glow of the lanterns against Nagasaki's hilly streets creates a nostalgic and vibrant atmosphere that attracts visitors from across the country during the winter months.

name: Karatsu Kunchi
short_description: UNESCO-recognized parade of giant, colorful lacquer floats (hikiyama).
description:
Held from November 2nd to 4th, Karatsu Kunchi is the annual festival of Karatsu Shrine. It features 14 massive floats (hikiyama) built in the 19th century using wood, clay, and layers of lacquer. The floats are shaped like lions, samurai helmets, and even sea bream (tai).

The festival is known for the participants' call of 'En-ya, En-ya!' as they pull the multi-ton floats through the streets and onto the sandy beach. The craftsmanship of the floats is world-renowned, and the sight of these colorful, centuries-old works of art being pulled by hundreds of locals is one of Kyushu's most important cultural traditions.

name: Akizuki 'Little Kyoto' Autumn
short_description: Historic castle town atmosphere framed by deep red maple leaves.
description:
Akizuki is an ancient castle town often called the 'Little Kyoto of Chikuzen.' In late November, the black 'Kuromon' gate of the former castle becomes a focal point as it is surrounded by vibrant red maples. The historical structures and the quiet, mountain-valley setting make it a premier foliage destination.

Visitors can enjoy a walk along the 'Sugi-no-baba' street, which is lined with cherry trees in spring and maples in autumn. Local shops sell traditional Japanese sweets and 'kuzu' (arrowroot) starch specialties. The area has a preserved, nostalgic feel that transport visitors back to the Edo period during the peak color season.

name: Kurokawa Onsen Yuakari
short_description: Warm winter glow of thousands of floating bamboo lanterns.
description:
From late December to early April, the famous hot spring village of Kurokawa Onsen hosts the 'Yuakari' light event. Thousands of 'mari-tōrō' (hollowed-out bamboo spheres with lights inside) are placed in the Tanoharu River and along the town's forested paths, creating a warm and ethereal atmosphere.

The light event was started using bamboo thinned from local forests to protect the mountain environment. The warm light reflecting on the steam from the river is especially beautiful during light snowfall. It is one of the most romantic winter destinations in Kyushu, perfect for visitors wearing yukata after a soak in the open-air baths.

name: Beppu Onsen Festival
short_description: A city-wide celebration of the world's most productive hot springs.
description:
Held in early April, this festival celebrates Beppu's hot springs. The 'Ogi-yama Fire Festival' is a highlight, where the slopes of Mt. Ogi are set ablaze in a controlled fire to mark the beginning of spring. It is one of the largest mountain fire festivals in Japan.

During the festival, many of the city's 100+ public baths offer free entry, and parades feature mikoshi (portable shrines) being showered with hot spring water. The event is a deep expression of the city's identity as Japan's 'Onsen Capital' and its gratitude to the geothermal heat that powers its local economy and tourism.

name: Kirishima Jingu Autumn Foliage
short_description: Vivid autumn leaves surrounding one of Kyushu's most sacred shrines.
description:
Kirishima Jingu is a grand shrine dedicated to Ninigi-no-mikoto, the grandson of the Sun Goddess. In November, the shrine's vermilion buildings are perfectly complemented by the surrounding forest of maples turning red. The shrine's location on the slopes of the volcanic Kirishima range adds to its majestic atmosphere.

The 'Sando' (approach) to the shrine is particularly famous for its tunnel of maple trees. Because the shrine is at a higher elevation, the colors here are often more intense than in the coastal areas. It is a popular spot for 'shichi-go-san' ceremonies and autumn photography, representing the intersection of Shinto faith and natural beauty.

name: Nanohana at Lake Ikeda
short_description: Golden fields of rape blossoms blooming against the backdrop of Mt. Kaimon.
description:
In Kagoshima's warm southern climate, the 'Nanohana' (rape blossoms) begin blooming as early as late December and peak in January. The fields surrounding Lake Ikeda offer a stunning view of millions of yellow flowers with 'Satsuma Fuji' (Mt. Kaimon) in the distance. It is one of the earliest signs of spring in Japan.

The area hosts the Ibusuki Nanohana Marathon in early January, which is Japan's first full marathon of the year. The golden fields against the deep blue of the lake and the perfect cone of the volcano make it one of Kyushu's most picturesque landscapes during the winter months.

name: Usuki Stone Buddhas Lotus Festival
short_description: Thousands of lotus flowers blooming beside ancient cliff-carved Buddhas.
description:
In July, the fields in front of the Usuki Stone Buddhas (magai-butsu) fill with lotus blossoms. These Buddhas are carved directly into the volcanic tuff cliffs and date back to the Heian and Kamakura periods. The lotus, a symbol of purity in Buddhism, provides a serene and historically appropriate setting for the site.

The festival includes 'Lotus Observation' tours in the early morning, as lotus flowers bloom at dawn and close by midday. The sight of these delicate, massive flowers in the morning mist against the ancient stone faces is one of Oita's most spiritual summer experiences.

name: Miyazaki Jingu Taisai
short_description: A grand historical parade featuring 'Shan-shan' horses and samurai.
description:
Held in late October, this festival is the most important annual event at Miyazaki Jingu. It features a grand historical parade (Jinmu-sama) where participants dress in traditional Heian and Edo period costumes. The highlight is the 'Shan-shan Uma,' horses decorated with bells and bright decorations carrying brides in traditional dress.

The festival celebrates the legendary first Emperor of Japan, Jinmu, who is enshrined at Miyazaki Jingu. The parade stretches for several kilometers and includes traditional music and lion dances. It is a major expression of Miyazaki's pride in its role as the 'cradle of Japanese mythology.'

name: Unzen Onsen Autumn Foliage
short_description: Vivid autumn colors in Kyushu's first designated National Park.
description:
Unzen is a mountain resort area famous for its 'Hell' (jigoku) steaming volcanic vents. In late October and early November, the entire mountain range, including Mt. Fugen and Mt. Myoken, is covered in brilliant autumn colors. The 'Miyama Kirishima' azaleas turn a unique reddish-brown, while maples provide bright crimson accents.

The Nita Pass offers a ropeway that provides an aerial view of the colors and the steaming vents below. On clear days, you can see all the way to the Ariake Sea and even Mt. Aso in the distance. The combination of autumn foliage and the stark white steam of the onsen vents creates a dramatic landscape unique to Nagasaki.

name: Hakata Dontaku Port Festival
short_description: Japan's largest Golden Week festival featuring a massive parade.
description:
Held on May 3rd and 4th, Hakata Dontaku is one of Japan's most attended festivals, drawing over 2 million visitors. The name 'Dontaku' comes from the Dutch word 'Zondag' (Sunday). The festival features a massive parade with groups called 'Zontaku' dancing with wooden spoons (shamoji) and playing music.

The festival's origin dates back to the 12th century as a celebration for the New Year. Today, there are dozens of stages throughout Fukuoka city hosting performances. It is a vibrant, inclusive event where everyone from local schools to international groups participates, making it the premier spring celebration in the city.

name: Kokura Castle Sakura
short_description: Cherry blossoms surrounding a unique 'Southern Style' castle tower.
description:
Kokura Castle in Kitakyushu features a unique architectural design where the fifth floor is larger than the fourth. In spring, approximately 300 cherry trees bloom in the castle park. The park is a popular spot for evening hanami, as the castle is lit up and lanterns are hung among the trees.

The castle is situated next to the ultra-modern Riverwalk Kitakyushu shopping complex, creating a striking visual contrast between old and new Japan. The castle's 'Shoin-zukuri' garden and teahouse also offer peaceful spots to enjoy the seasonal flowers in a traditional setting.

name: Kuju Flower Park Spring Bloom
short_description: Vast fields of flowers blooming on the slopes of the Kuju Mountains.
description:
While the park has flowers from spring to autumn, the spring season (April-May) is particularly famous for its pink moss (shibazakura), tulips, and nemophila. The park covers 20 hectares on a high plateau, offering panoramic views of the Kuju mountain range.

The 'Pink Moss' carpet is a signature sight, creating a vibrant purple-pink landscape that contrasts with the deep green of the mountains. The clean air and high altitude make for very bright, saturated flower colors. It is a popular destination for nature lovers and families touring the scenic 'Aso-Kuju' region.

name: Arita Ceramic Fair
short_description: A massive Golden Week market in the birthplace of Japanese porcelain.
description:
Held from April 29th to May 5th, this is one of Japan's largest ceramic markets. The main street of Arita, spanning 4 kilometers, is lined with over 500 stalls selling Arita-yaki porcelain at discounted prices. The town has been a center for porcelain production since the 17th century.

Over a million pottery enthusiasts visit the fair to hunt for bargains and rare pieces. The event includes special exhibitions at local museums and the chance to visit historic kiln sites. The bustling, festive atmosphere in this otherwise quiet mountain town is a unique seasonal experience for those interested in Japanese craft and history.

name: Tobata Gion Yamakasa
short_description: A unique festival where floats transform into glowing light pyramids.
description:
Held in late July, this festival is famous for its 'Chochin Yamakasa' (Lantern Floats). During the day, the floats are decorated with flags, but as night falls, the decorations are removed and replaced with 12 layers of 309 lanterns, forming a pyramid of light 10 meters tall.

The spectacle of men carrying these glowing, swaying pyramids of light through the streets is recognized as a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage. The coordination required to carry such heavy, top-heavy structures is immense, and the festival is a source of great local pride in the Tobata district of Kitakyushu.

name: Yanagawa Hinamatsuri
short_description: Elaborate 'Sagamon' decorations and boat parades for the Doll Festival.
description:
From mid-February to early April, the canal city of Yanagawa celebrates the Hinamatsuri (Doll Festival) with a unique local tradition called 'Sagamon.' These are hanging decorations made of colorful silk balls and small dolls, believed to bring happiness and long life to daughters.

The highlight is the 'Ohina-sama Water Parade' in mid-March, where children and participants dressed in Heian-period robes travel through the city's canals on flat-bottomed boats. The mix of colorful decorations, blossoming willow trees, and the slow pace of the canal boats makes for a beautiful and nostalgic spring event.

name: Kagoshima Ohara Matsuri
short_description: Southern Kyushu's largest dance festival with over 20,000 performers.
description:
Held on November 2nd and 3rd, the Ohara Matsuri is a major celebration of Kagoshima's culture. Over 20,000 dancers in yukata and traditional costume parade through the streets of Tenmonkan, performing to the rhythm of the 'Ohara-bushi' folk song.

The festival includes both daytime and nighttime dance sessions. The energy is lively and welcoming, with the active Sakurajima volcano often providing a dramatic backdrop. It is a great event to experience the distinct 'Satsuma' spirit of the southern island and enjoy local Kagoshima food at the many street stalls.

name: Usuki Bamboo Lantern Festival
short_description: Historic castle town illuminated by 30,000 bamboo lanterns.
description:
Held in early November, the 'Usuki Take-akari' transforms the historic castle town into a sea of soft light. Approximately 30,000 bamboo lanterns (take-dōrō) are placed along the streets and in front of samurai residences and temples.

The event commemorates the local history and the legendary figure 'Ma-no-Choja.' The soft, warm light creates a quiet and reverent atmosphere, perfect for exploring the well-preserved Edo-period architecture of Usuki. It is widely considered one of the most beautiful and peaceful bamboo lantern festivals in Japan.
